title: Bedgebury Forest Walks and Mtb

images.title: Colin Smith / Bedgebury Pinetum
images.caption: Bedgebury Pinetum.  Bluebells blooming beside the "Spring Walk" path through the world's largest pinetum.

images.title: Nigel Chadwick, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Great Lake, Bedgebury Park. The Bell Bedgebury International School is to the right of the photo. This is part of the Bedgebury Estate, which dates back to the 9th century. The lake is a good spot for seeing waterfowl.

images.title: Colin Smith / Bedgebury Pinetum
images.caption: Bedgebury Pinetum. Specimen conifers on the hillside south-east of Marshal's Lake.

images.title: David Anstiss / Track in Bedgebury forest
images.caption: Track in Bedgebury forest. This track heads northwards. It is part of a red route mountain bike trail around the forest. Seen from the bridleway near Three Chimneys Bank.

images.title: Colin Smith / Rhododendron at Bedgebury
images.caption: Red flowering rhododendron beside a pond in the Pinetum. In the distance, left, is the edge of the Leyland Cypress hedge.

images.title: Colin Smith / Forest Trail, Bedgebury
images.caption: Waymarker post for the family cycle trail. A dense network of signposted trails exists in the Forest with many open to cyclists. Some, like the one pictured, are on nice easy surfaced paths suitable for families or anyone looking for an easy ride.

images.title: Oast House Archive / View towards Bedgebury Park
images.caption: View towards Bedgebury Park over the fields. Formerly used as a school this impressive building is Grade II* listed.

images.title: Colin Smith / Hillside in Bedgebury Pinetum
images.caption: Hillside in the Pinetum. Flowering broom in the foreground, bluebells on the grassy slope in middleground, specimen conifers can be seen in the background.

description: Bedgebury is a great place for cyclists with miles of family cycle tracks and a more challenging mountain bike trail. The gentle 10km trail is perfect for exploring the 2000 acre forest at a leisurely pace on generally flat surfaced paths. Adrenalin junkies can enjoy 13km of single-track mountain biking. It's generally graded as a red trail and has fast sweeping gradual descents and some challenging climbs. There's also cycle shop where you can hire a bike. The forest is also great for walkers with miles of peaceful woodland trails to follow. You can enjoy a stroll around the beautiful Bedgebury Pinetum. This recreational and conservational arboretum has 10,000 trees growing across 320 acres including the most complete collection of conifers on one site in the world. If you would like to extend your exercise then you can head to the nearby Bewl Water and enjoy a splendid 12.5 mile cycling and walking trail.
